title: See and Be Seen
subtitle: Art is about communication, says Bob Brandy. Showing your work is an important part of the process.

cards.text: For me, showing work in public has always been an essential part of being a painter. As a schoolboy preparing for my final Art examination, I had a large landscape painting accepted at the annual exhibition in Stockport and was delighted when it sold during the opening evening. The pleasure of being there, among proper artists, convinced me that painting was for me.
cards.question: What effect did exhibiting in Stockport have on the writer?
choices: It brought him to the attention of other artists.
It made him realise what he wanted to do.
It overcame his lack of confidence.
It changed his future plans.
cards.highlight: convinced me that painting was for me

cards.text: In fact, it took nearly 40 years for me to become a full-time painter, but in that time I kept working at my craft through evening classes.
cards.question: Despite his early success, the writer
choices: lost interest in painting.
was not satisfied with his own pictures.
did not follow a career in painting.
ignored public opinion of his ability.
cards.highlight: it took nearly 40 years for me to become a full-time painter

cards.text: There I discovered that many part-time painters are unwilling to show their work in public. They give the reason that 'it's not good enough', but what they really fear is being rejected or, worse still, being shown but not appreciated.
cards.question: According to the writer, why do part-time painters criticise their own work?
choices: To explain their absence from exhibitions.
To impress others with their knowledge.
To hide their pride in their own efforts.
To invite praise from other artists.
cards.highlight: what they really fear is being rejected or, worse still, being shown but not appreciated

cards.text: Once your work is accepted for one of these shows, you may take pleasure in discovering that, compared with some of the work, yours doesn't look bad! ...while straining to hear what people say about yours. We all do it!
cards.question: What does 'yours' (line 32) refer to?
choices: Ability
Work
Outlook
Pleasure

cards.text: Next, you'll be tempted to wait around near your work, apparently staring at somebody else's picture while straining to hear what people say about yours. We all do it!
cards.question: Artists at an exhibition may pretend to be looking at someone else's work in order to
choices: show that they are interested in improving.
find out how much it is worth.
avoid having to talk to the visitors.
hear opinions about their own paintings.
cards.highlight: straining to hear what people say about yours

cards.text: Using the same standard of judgement, consider what you have tried to say. Have you done better or worse than the others? Looking as a critic and not as the fond artist, what would you say your paintings are about?
cards.question: The writer uses the phrase 'the fond artist' (line 50) to indicate a painter who may
choices: ignore the opinions of the exhibition visitors.
agree too quickly with the ideas of other artists.
be too generous in considering his or her own work.
be unable to find faults in the works of others.
cards.highlight: Looking as a critic and not as the fond artist

cards.text: When comparing their work with that of others, artists should avoid becoming depressed, bored, jealous or angry.
cards.question: When comparing their work with that of others, artists should avoid becoming
choices: depressed.
bored.
jealous.
angry.
cards.highlight: artists should avoid becoming depressed, bored, jealous or angry

cards.text: From this process of looking and learning you will realise that painting is all about communicating: passing on your enthusiasm for your subject to a viewer who is probably quite unknown.
cards.question: This article concentrates on painting as a means of
choices: spending time enjoyably.
passing on ideas.
making a reputation.
earning a living.
cards.highlight: painting is all about communicating: passing on your enthusiasm
